content: Updated the wording in the statement to make it clearer.

it takes time to understand this, it is good. 
but in clash of 15 minutes. i dont think it is good here.

Here are a few remarks:

- As noticed by Zorg1, the Q in Q1, Q2, etc. is a bit strange for someone who doesn't speak french (Q = quille = pin).
- I wonder why you choose to put a limitation of 4 rounds (we can solve the problem without the limitation with dynamic programming, but the puzzle becomes medium/hard).
- You should say explicitly that we put back the fallen pins between each round.
- Tests/Validators are not equivalent, which has to be fixed.


That being said, it is a nice proposal (we don't have that many puzzles about combinatorics) and I was able to find the same results as your code.

"-If a player drops only one pin, he scores the number of points written on that pin.
-If a player does 'not' knock down more than one pin, he marks the number of pins knocked down."
basically, the first is to explain what happens if only 1 has dropped, but the second point is also the same. Am i right in removing the 'not' ? or have i understood it the wrong way?

Hello everyone, this project is not yet been validated for several reasons: 
-I proposed this puzzle some people understood the instructions, others did not. So I am taking any advice to make it clearer.
-I would also like to be sure of the reliability of my answer and therefore of the validators if several people could create the answer algorithm and compare with the answer of the validators it would be nice.
-Finally, the most important thing I would like to know if this puzzle can please the community and therefore whether it is necessary for me to redouble my efforts to perfect it.

Hello, thank you for your comments, I would like to correct some of them but on the other hand, I would like to come back to some points)
-It is true that I have decided to use the letter "Q" to designate a pin and that it corresponds to the French word, but I remind you in the instruction that the letter "Q" is used and its importance so you don't need to be French to understand
-The problem if I put a lot of rounds it will create too many possibilities and would be too long to list (that said, I can be wrong if you have an idea I would be happy if you told me)
-And sorry I don't understand why you say that tests and validators are not equivalent, could you demonstrate it with an example

For the rest, I agree and I understand your comments. I will try to make the changes as soon as possible. Thank you again for your participation.
But if it takes time to find the answer, putting it in clash of code would be a bad idea, the risk would be that the participants would not finish on time

- I don't really mind about the use of Q, but P would be more logical.

- You don't have to list all the possibilities in order to count them. A usual trick in this situation is "dynamic programming". 

- Test 3 and Validator 3 should be the same (Only one == 49 at start). This is a situation where having the same test and validator is acceptable.

Test 1 and Validator 1 are not the same. With 47, you don't have to take the limit of 4 rounds into account, while this point does matter with 38.
Okay, I take note of all this, but I fear that dynamic programming requires some knowledge that I am not if you have a site or I could discover this I am a taker.

More details on dynamic programming.

The idea is to fill an array indexed with the starting score and compute the number of possibilities from i=50 down to 0. 


* T[50] = 1 

There is only 1 way to score 50 starting from 50, which is doing nothing.


* T[i] = T[i+1] + 2 * sum(T[i+j], j=2..12, i+j<=50)

Starting from i<50, you can reach 50 by either:
- knock down Q1 and start again with a current score of i+1
--> T[i+1] follow-ups

- knock down Qj and start again with a current score of i+j
--> sum(T[i+j], j=2..12, i+J<=50) follow-ups

- knock down j pins at once and start again with a current score of i+j
--> again sum(T[i+j], j=2..12, i+J<=50) follow-ups.
